definition: Chen Xiangmei (1925-2018), a.k.a. Anna Chennault, born in Beijing, US Republican Party politician, wife of Claire Lee Chennault 陳納德|陈纳德[Chen2 na4 de2]
surname Chen/Chen (c. 1045 - 479 BC), a Zhou dynasty state/Chen (557-589), one of the Southern Dynasties 南朝[Nan2 Chao2]
to lay out/to exhibit/to display/to narrate/to state/to explain/to tell/old/stale
fragrant/sweet smelling/aromatic/savory or appetizing/(to eat) with relish/(of sleep) sound/perfume or spice/joss or incense stick/CL:根[gen1]
old variant of 梅[mei2]
surname Mei
variant of 梅[mei2]
plum/plum flower/Japanese apricot (Prunus mume)

sentences.english: After his death, Anna settled in the U. S. with their two children.
sentences.chinese: 丈夫去世之后，陈香梅带着两个孩子在美国定居。

sentences.english: She was one of initiators of "Teachers' Day" in China.
sentences.chinese: 陈香梅女士是中国教师节的发起人之一。

definition: Song Qingling or Rosemonde Soong (1893-1981), wife of Sun Yat-sen 孫中山|孙中山[Sun1 Zhong1 shan1]
Soong Mei-ling (1898-2003), Chiang Kai-shek's second wife
Qiao Guanhua (1913-1973), PRC politician and diplomat
(Claire) Chennault, commander of Flying Tigers during World War II
Han Suyin (1917-2012), Eurasian physician and author

John Leighton Stuart (1876-1962), second-generation American missionary in China, first president of Yenching University and later United States ambassador to China
Zhou Enlai (1898-1976), Chinese communist leader, prime minister 1949-1976
Pearl S. Buck (1892-1973), American writer known for her novels on Asian cultures, Pulitzer Prize and Nobel Prize laureate
Li Zongren (1891-1969), a leader of Guangxi warlord faction
Agnes Smedley (1892-1950), US journalist and activist, reported on China, esp. the communist side
Chiang Ching-kuo (1910-1988), son of Chiang Kai-shek 蔣介石|蒋介石, Guomindang politician, president of ROC 1978-1988
Wang Daohan (1915-2005), former president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits
Zhang Zhizhong (1890-1969), National Revolutionary Army general
Zhang Shizhao (1881-1973), revolutionary journalist in Shanghai, then established writer
Chiang Wei-kuo (1916-1997), adopted son of Chiang Kai-shek 蔣介石|蒋介石
